review_title: Good for shareholders, bad for clients and employees
pros: BB&T offers excellent benefits, a 6% match and vestment into a pension after five years. Advancement usually occurs from within. cons: Stress and helplessness. That is how your position will be defined, regardless of your title. Branches are staffed at such a minimal level that associates are constantly treading water. Sales goals are determined by some abstract process performed outside of your market and goals are expected to be met, regardless of how many vacancies are at your branch. job_title: Branch Banker in Hope Mills, NC
pros: good benefits and good hours.

I was a exemplary associate. I'm sadden by this. Feel like I'm getting a divorce after being dependable and loyal for many, many years. BB&T now expects nothing but perfection! 'non-negotiable' !!! The staff is expected to work with a very, very lean staff to reach unrealistic goals. Which creates disgruntled clients. Which means the tellers get the brunt of the client complaints of the long wait time.  BB&T is about the bottom line instead of how the client might perceive their banking experience.  Clients don't understand that with every banking transaction, the bank associate's job may be on the line. Something I took lightly which cost me my job.  I remember a time in my 32 years, where my manager would fight for me. I was shown the door...'NON-NEGOTIABLE'!!

The scheduling is horrible, one day off in 12, usually three 10 hour days a week, but there is no overtime, so you constantly have to enter less hours than you actually work to keep it under 39.5 per week.  You are micro-managed to death.  This place will burn you out in a matter of months.  Obviously, since these are the same issues that were mentioned years ago, management couldn't care less.

If you are interested in being treated as a professional take a pass. They also have a time off accrual calendar where you don't accrue your last day until the last day of the year and it is use or lose. This results in always having a negative balance which doesn't seem like a big deal until they cut your final paycheck in half. The place is petty and it permeates the culture the successful managers are people who have learned to escape accountability and  stay quiet about the complete lack of a technology strategy.

job_title: Market Leader V in Norfolk, VA
pros:
Excellent training and “university” 
Technology for branch operations
cons:
Unrealistic expectations and impossibility of family work life balance in the branch environment.  Sales expectations, scheduling and limitation of employee empowerment to make battlefield decisions. Policy overrides common sense in most situations. Lack  of ability to provide exceptional service.   Limited support for managers to coach and grow their teams because managers are expected to be the lead sales champions.  Lack of independent thinking (another core value) and fostering an environment to solve problems on your own.
Unfair and deceptive practices regarding goals and “matrix” - lack of transparency from senior leadership.  Inability to grow or move out of the branch if you are successful (senior management wants to keep you in the position even if you are above qualifications for role)  unstaffed branches and too many branches in market areas.  Pride and ownership are not evident amongst regions.

pros: Great benefits, attainable goals, work/life balance
cons: Short staffed constantly, productive employees are not recognized for meeting or exceeding goals. Software is outdated and slow. Too much upper management, who are never seen visiting the branches to observe what cutting jobs is doing to the moral of the employees and trust of the customers,

pros: BB&T is a company that is extremely family oriented. All the managers that I have spoken with and worked for go above and beyond to work with their employee's when I come to situation outside of work that involve family. BB&T also requires there workers to take a 5 day vacation at some point throughout the year. This is meant to give employees an extended vacation completely disconnected form work to be able to rest and relax.
cons: BB&T is a company that in the resent past has acquired many regional banks. In the process of transitioning the new assets and personnel there have been times workers felt overwhelmed.

pros: Salary is great, room for advancement if motivated. My direct manager was great, gave me more responsibilities as time went on. I was very appreciative of that. I loved to show my capabilities and loved challenging myself.
cons:
-Harassment from team members to go against compliance. It’s a bully type of environment if you don’t give into peer pressure. Getting pressured to do things the easy way instead of the correct way is not a good feeling, especially when no one speaks to you after doing the right thing. I will never go back to working with people like that.
-Physical branch was disgusting, leaks into carpet, leaks from ceiling, immense amount of dust, oh also a customer actually took a dump in the trash can in our bathroom and one of our team members was told to clean it, location was horrible.
-Favoritism definitely exists amongst team members, not inclusive of whole team. Was a huge wake up call. 
-Vacation is minimal. 
-Systems not user friendly, extremely out dated.

pros: Good work - life balance and helpful training at BB&T University
cons: Company eliminated unpaid vacation in 2012 due to a lawsuit.  Unpaid vacation days not available.  Paid 10 days for many employees.   Assistant VP & VP get 15 paid days.  Senior VP get 20 days. You get more days for length of service - at 5 years & 10 years bonus vacation days. You get standard bank holidays (Christmas, New Year, Thanksgiving, etc).

job_title: Relationship Banker in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: The upper management is very reception to conversation if you are a performer.  If not, I can't say the same.  The benefits are very good.  The hours are great, and the working environment is very good.
cons: The lower level management structure is not good.  Retail managers act in a manner consistent with call center managers.  Rewards are "dangled" to motivate staff with not much hope of achieving goals.  Coaching sessions are more like inquiry or interrogations.   The title of manager should lend to the assumption that the individual holding the title has the ability to effectively manage a staff.  Unfortunately that is not the case.  The branch manager, or FCL, (in my experience) does not typically have the ability to handle pressure or stress appropriately.  Thusly, the staff bears the weight.  Not good at all.

job_title: Customer Service Representative I in Lititz, PA
pros: Got to keep my job with the merge and got a raise (but now that the new hires are making $3+/hour more than the existing reps I don't even think this would be considered a pro)
cons: Bare minimum training during the process of the merge (probably meaning they're going to get rid of us), micromanaging, hiring 50+ people in 2 months, overdraft fees based on algorithm within the computer system(?), and hiring new people making $17/hour whereas the typical CSR makes just above $14. Not fair in the slightest how you run this company.

pros: Great training, if you ever have a question about something you can call branch info for help.
cons: Not open about what is going on. You never get to interact with top managers so they don't get to know you, but these are the managers that control your career. They move employees around too much which makes the clients nervous. They have started moving away from their great mission statement and no longer are putting communities and employees first, it is all about the shareholders. If you make a big mistake you could be let go.

review_title: The worse experience of my professional career.
pros: ON THE SURFACE- life force, 401k, pension plan.
cons: This particular branch was the worse experience of my life. There was SO much going on I would be ASHAMED for KELLY KING to know! Politics, people backstabbing one another, management covering for their pets! Disgusting!!!!! Upper management "grooming their pets" to be whatever they want them to be. Never had a more disappointing experience IN MY LIFE!  Disgusting how HUMAN beings are taken out of the equation all together.... Nothing but market leaders trying to make themselves look good, whoring after whatever sale opportunity they can, whoring themselves and their employees!!! Despicable! I could see right through what was going on at this company. Listen, DO NOT WASTE your time,  and I mean your emotional time at this company!!!! Very alarming, misleading, basically they will try and sell this amazing job offer to you and once you get there it is like the worse job ever.

pros: The hours and bank holidays
cons: My manager was very young and did not have managerial experience. He was promoted because he was good at sales. Reason being that’s all the company cares about. Bankers are supposed to make 50 cold calls a week. Credit cards and loans are pushed heavily under the disguise of solutions. Upper management is on retail managers back constantly and our area manager persistently berated my manager. Nothing was good enough. It is a high pressure sales environment even though we should have been focused on just helping customers. Every customer was supposed to be viewed as a potential sale. The environment/culture was terrible. Most of coworkers supported trump and they were vocal about it. Cursing at tv when Hilary gave concession speech calling her curse words. Employees getting fired to save money raise stock price and employees left have to work twice as hard. Older coworker was pushed out because she was out too many days for flu and for her age.

review_title: Moving forward while stuck in the past by stepping on the employees.
pros:
Extremely large and diverse product and service set.
Seemingly competitive payscale.
Plenty of openings & availabilities.
cons:
"To Big To Fail" in a nutshell. Extremely similar to Wells Fargo in both origin and styling.
Constant mergers mean no stability or regularity on a regional level. 
Processes are extremely outdated and rigid.
Policy does not allow for adaptation depending on branch layout, staffing levels, market area, regional need, or special circumstances.
Branch network built around having few full timers who are required to work extreme hours, and several part timers who are expected to work varied and unreliable staffing schedules as determined by computer algorithm. 
Growth and advancement positions posted for extremely short periods of time, and given to individuals too quickly for many - if any - interviews to take place. 
Lack of cohesiveness and consistency across entire spectrum of departments.
No centralized support network. Several departments responsible for "support" often send employees back and forth.

review_title: I have truly enjoyed working for BB&T.
pros: I've been here more than 5 years, BB&T offers excellent benefits. The option to "buy a week of vacation" comes in handy. I now have 4 weeks of vacation because I used that option. They offer vision, dental, health, 401K, and several life insurance options. I read a lot of comments about brain washing. BB&T does like a consistent feel throughout the Footprint so you can walk into a bank in Florida or one in Tennessee and feel like you got the same high quality service. When you work for a paycheck you are expected to the job & do it right. I've read a lot of reviews that say BB&T micromanages its employees. I get what they are going for, that consistent feel for the client. BB&T is there for you as an employee if you are there for BB&T doing your job right!
cons: Sales are the only way to move up the ladder if you work in a branch. Again, I understand this because opening accounts means more business. If you aren't impressing the management with the numbers you aren't moving up!

review_title: Staid company full of middling talent
pros: Good 401(k) match, you won't get fired here, talented workers can really stand out, well-defined corporate culture.
cons: Poor technology, little understanding of the market outside of traditional core customers, inflexible work from home policy, no interest in innovation, 1970s-style employee benefits, sub-market pay. There's a tendency to denigrate the competition without studying them for best practices.  Facilities project a poor image to clients and associates. Management does not recognize that the workforce has changed- should rethink compensation and benefits to appeal to a younger, more talented crowd (no pension, better vacation, work from home, etc.)

job_title: ML Underwriter III in Greensboro, NC
pros: Company has good benefit package including 401K, insurance coverage and pension plan.  Flex hours to a degree.
cons: Very unorganized management team.  Inconsistent management where managers do not even know 101 underwriting.  Very overworked with extremely long hours and their method of "acknowledgement" is to allow you to wear jeans on Friday.  Too sales and volume driven with no focus on quality loans.  Appears BB&T is headed down the road where banks went in the great crash back in 2007 and 2008.  Managers push and push the employees, but do not jump in to help the employees out by helping to underwrite, clear loan conditions.  If they choose to do so, they are very critical of the underwriter's work but in turn these are the same managers who do not even know the basics of underwriting.

pros:
The company has great benefits and pay.
Depending on your department you will have great coworkers and leadership.
Has decent stability and security, depending on your job.
Great flexibility.
Community events.
If you are just wanting a job to collect a pay check and aren't passionate about it then you'll do great here.
cons:
Company is stuck in the dark ages technologically.
Doesn't listen to advice.
Very slow moving.
Not willing or wanting to change.
Just talks without action (this could be the department managers and not executive management).
Hires incompetent people and won't let them go.
Only focused on numbers and what can be quantified on paper.

pros: Upper management is always helpful. Some good people to work with. 2018 minimum rate of $15 per hour. 6% 401-k match.  Stable company. Room for growth in movement to management or other levels as long as you have the education or experience.
cons: Your direct supervisor on the teller like may be horrible. If so it’s very difficult to work because your life is now a drama movie, where everything is a big deal. Workplace is a very fast environment. Clients often get mad about waiting in line. No music. Very quiet all day. A lot of stress. Never get home on time. They expect you to take extra time on your lunch break for when you run over your time at nights. They won’t pay overtime. They won’t let you progress from the teller line. It’s a fight the whole way to get more training. Responsibilities are not shared between Employees, so if you start something you’ll be doing it till you quit.

pros:
401k
The potential of free health insurance for yourself
Average vacation plan
Sick days are treated differently than PTO
cons:
Sales goals are almost unreachable for everyone starting 2019
Branch Bankers are expected to do 90% of branch goals
Required to submit vacation request a month in advance

review_title: RIF's are getting to be the NORM
pros:
Full benefits for PT employees.
Holidays, vacation, and birthday's off
cons:
Lots of micro-managing--conference calls, meetings, call nights, reports to complete when management can pull the results themselves.
Stressful work environment--the impression of never doing enough.
Sales goals that are unattainable.

pros: Small underwriting team, convenient to the DART train system
cons: Lack of training, bad leadership appears they all came with hidden agendas not focused on BB&T core values. Dallas RPST Operations leader appeared to target anyone she didn't hire personally.  Also, her minions played the same tactics. I wouldn't work at this place ever again if JESUS said it was my ticket into the Kingdom of Heaven.  Prior to June/July 2015 I heard this place was a productive environment new management came in and the place is a "Operational Risk". Do not work here not an environment that allows candid feedback or open dialogue.

pros: Great benefits, value-driven culture, generous, caring, engaged colleagues.
cons: Not enough FTEs, which leads to exec management expectations unrealistic to successful and thorough execution (at least not without returning to the problematic atmosphere of skillfully unspoken but subtly pressured overtime for exempt employees).  The watercooler talk is heightening regarding long-term, dedicated associates considering outside opportunities due to sheer work/life balance burn-out.

review_title: not a fit if that is what you are 'seeking'
pros: perhaps their overall compensation benefits...but it's a lie and joke to say the pay is 'competitive', if you negotiate a 'good' salary, you 'may' be fine, but trying to really go up professionally, or 'relying' on those 'annual raises' ...you will be waiting 10-20 years before you see that 'bump' in compensation
cons: you never 'catch up' with pay, when problems arise, it's more of a 'who to blame, what to blame, rather than what was the problem, or really finding out the root cause of the problem, it's a major - COVER YOUR OWN @$$ environment, see and hear backtracking, saying one thing one moment and something else the next minute...

review_title: If you are looking into retail banking turn the other direction and run.
pros: Good public perception, strong capital levels, 6% 401k match, pension.
cons:
POOR technology base.
Relatively low salary and 2% or less annual increases (if you get one at all).
Branch managers and their employees are brainwashed and cannot successfully complete work load.
Service mentality has become overrun with sales first, sales second, service third.
Unrealistic goals.
Incredibly confusing goal structure, even the creators do not know what's going on most of the time.
Upper-level management suffers from a huge disconnect.
With record profits, many of us wonder where all the profits go to, it sure doesn't to go salaries of the front line employees.
Retail managers are annually reviewed/promoted by regional managers that visit branches maybe 8 times or less a year.
I work 50++ hours a week for a salary that is at least 20k lower than the average competitor.

review_title: I loved my job but not my coworkers!
pros: Great benefits! Lovely clients! If you love helping people, this is the place to be! Corporate is very culturally diverse. They will work with you on almost anything.
cons: Dispersed branch locations (rural areas) get away with a lot of things they shouldn't be able to. BB&T leaves a very Christian environment that shouldn't be allowed into the workplace. It also encourages certain discrimination based on sexual orientation, gender, and race: all of which I experienced while working for BB&T.

pros: Great benefits, co-workers and competitive pay.  Depending on your manager and your level of performance, you may be micro-managed, or allowed a bit of freedom to complete your duties.  Managers I've worked with have always made an attempt to grant your vacation or make work hours flexible to accommodate your personal life.
cons: High level of attrition and, like many other companies today, they are focused dearly on the bottom line - meaning you're expendable.  Given the losses we've sustained, much of the work has been pushed onto the already full plates of other teams and groups, even if the tasks are not even remotely related to your job description.

pros: BB&T has an admirable mission and culture statement. There are a lot of in-house promotions and with the level of turnover you can move quickly from teller to management  assuming  you are liked by the right people.  The company provides  a great deal of  training if you choose to pursue it.
cons:
Some of the systems and processes are ancient which result in frequent errors.  The fees are also extremely high. This upsets clients which is a problem when your job is to keep clients happy. 
Every department is divided by what they have access to and your job is interdependent on the competence of others. There is a high rate of turnover. A great deal of pressure is out on managers to perform. This stress is then passed onto employees which can create a depressing environment where they are not empowered nor given the resources, tools or encouragement to succeed.

job_title: Mortgage Loan Processor in Charleston, WV
pros: Lower management is great. They are very helpful and always have their door open. Coworkers are also very friendly and everyone helps each other out.
cons: The work load varies by the time of year and can some times be unmanageable. If you are a hard worker you are often taken advantage of by being given a heavier work load, while others get away with a lower work load and taking breaks every hour. People that slack off are rarely reprimanded, which is very frustrating. Over time is occasionally offered, but they usually wait until everyone is so far behind it is impossible to catch up. There is very little opportunity for advancement and promotions are given as a title with no pay increase. With promotions you are expected to take more difficult files, but you don't get paid anymore to do it. Upper management rules with threats and rarely recognizes achievements. They turn what could be a positive enjoyable work environment into a frustrating and negative environment.

review_title: BB&T has more opportunities, benefits, & ethics than any company I've studied.
pros:
The benefits are absolutely phenomenal!  There is a heavy concentration on culture, professionalism, and ethics.  The competitive differentiator for the company is keeping the small bank feel while expanding nationally.  
The LDP program is 10 months in Winston-Salem, which is a beautiful city with a lot of history.  Surprisingly, the cost of living is also relatively low.  One of the program's primary intentions is embedding the culture into the associates so that we can reinforce them in all areas of the company.
There are frequent opportunities to meet Executive Managers, including the CEO.
cons: The Leadership Development Program has been highly expanded over the past decade, and facilitators are frequently changing, adding, and updating the program for greater efficiency.  The downside is that you won't have a precise schedule for more than a few months in advance, although you are aware of what to expect on a macro level.

review_title: Great benefit, great dream of bonus, but horrible at recognizing issues
pros: The benefits are expensive but expansive.  Many different options when it comes to retirement planning and insurance. Also competitive business products.
cons: If you don't mind working 6 days a week and 13 hour work days, please apply to this company. I used to work for this company and it was difficult to even have a home life outside of BB&T. They were not concerned about anything but the bottom line, with unattainable goals and ridiculous incentive plan. When I started I was intrigued by the rigorous training program and the opportunity to earn half my salary in bonuses. Well that was all I got, training and a dream. Brainwashed to learn the culture and expected to live it in my everyday life. Basically live for BB&T. So if you choose them, don't fall for the dreams they sell.

pros:
- 401(k) match is excellent
- Health Insurance coverage is reasonable and opportunity to participate in a wellness program can result in lower premium expenses
- Generally colleagues are great to work with and the conservative risk appetite has ensured solid financial footing over the years
- Onsite wellness clinic for common ailments with some free prescriptions available
- Work/life balance is generally good despite staffing levels
cons:
- Extreme cost consciousness has lead to bare bones staffing levels and lower morale
- Not always prone to promoting from within
- Culture has changed over the last 5 years from its rooted essence of a community bank that has its community and associates at heart.  Focus now seems to be heavily on shareholders with investments into associates diminished.

review_title: It's a decent place to work if you have a good territory/book
pros: Great benefits, you are largely free to do what you want within your territory, you are a revenue producer and important to the organization in that respect, the brand of the bank is at its best ever due to its performance during the economic downturn, they cover mileage, provide a laptop and phone.  You will have a territory of several branches from which you will be exclusive investment representative.  Great leadership on the bank side.
cons: You cannot count on your branch network to give adequate referrals to reach your goal.  I would ask for a book of business of no less than 30 million to give you a reasonable chance of attaining goal and a decent payout.  Some reps complain about the compliance department and product offerings but I have no major problem with either.  I will say the ship is run tighter than most other places but that's why they avoided many of the headlines other brokerages suffered with.

review_title: My experience at BB&T can be explained as a rollercoaster ride.
pros: This job has great benefits and they match your 401k plan. You're not made to sell products however you must call people a couple times a day. Plus, I only worked every 3rd Saturday.  It was required that you work every Saturday. It's a great entry level job for someone who has normal retail experience. Paid holidays as well.
cons: Had very catty women working there making the environment unbearable. My manager didn't push his team a lot.He spent more time in his office watching sports on his phone instead of going out and getting clientele for the branch. They also have many unnecessary rules and it's easy to get in trouble over small things as a teller.

pros: Benefits were not bad, they still offer pension.
cons: no opportunity for growth. short staffed, moving towards 100% sales. vacation is 10 days for 5 years after 5th year you get another week for the next 5 years. there is definitely a buddy buddy system, you are either in the man club or your not, if you are in you will grow and have a lot of opportunity if not good luck! and managers, upper managers do not know how how to do any of the work they are asking the employees to do.

review_title: As if BB&T's performance during this financial crisis is not evident enough...
pros: Not only is it currently the highest performing financial services company in the region, the corporate culture is evident in the day-to-day operations of the company and not merely a set of words printed on an index card and forgotten.  The current management is committed and competent, and the exposure and ability to advance is there when sought.  The overall compensation value is one of the best in the industry, and it seems every employee is very content with his or her job.  It seems like half of BB&T's employees have left other banks to come work for BB&T, and the other half have been with BB&T for their entire career.
cons: There is not a whole lot of vacation time given out in the beginning of one's BB&T career, and there is not a whole lot of room for advancement of those whose work ethic is lacking.

pros: Good benefits, pay ok but somewhat low compared to market, great brand which has pulled the company along in spite of missteps.
cons: Confusion as to how the company should proceed in the future.  CEO is too disconnected from reality and what goes on below him.  In recent years a great deal of outside management has come into BB&T from other banks.  While this is needed some of them are to self-serving and political.  Community Bank has lost it's way and must be rebuilt culturally.  Credit Administration is sitting in the back seat now and being bullied by the field without support from their managers.  Many associates do not have the basic skills needed to succeed.

pros: BB&T still matches 6% on the 401k and employees are still eligible for a pension. As long as you are close to hitting your goals your superiors will leave you alone. They have decent training for lenders on how credit works. Still one of the last big banks to give lenders loan authority.
cons: Way behind the curve in technology which is very frustrating. Communication between leadership and the branches is nonexistent. The leadership has closed ears and do not listen to anyone that questions the why or how things are done.  Everyone is made to give  the same canned speech to clients and prospects...its embarrassing and clients will call you out on it. BB&T is so slow on communication and technology that you won't be able to see how you are doing in your yearly goals until June or July...that's pathetic. And your goals will change without  warning.

review_title: My department was better than the overall corporation
pros: The people are awesome. Work-life balance was great (good vacation) and the company is very ethical and promotes family values. I had an awesome supervisor. He/She was "one of us" before getting promoted, so really understood the work.
cons:
In my specific role, there was not room for advancement. Once my boss got promoted, that's it -- they would have to leave before another opp for advancement came open. (We were a pretty specialized team.) So, it was out-to-go-up for me. I think Senior Management (outside of our building), and some of the product managers as well, had no idea what we did on a day-to-day, or how specialized/difficult it was. So, I think we were under-appreciated outside of our team. 

Also, even though we were a non-client-facing team, we had to dress the part ("because everyone else has to.")

review_title: Overall a good company to work for!
pros: Culture, Management, Co-Workers, 401K Match.
cons: Sometimes stressful, robotic sales approach, constant change of procedures.

review_title: The Investment Counselor Position is a Dog with Frontline Immune Fleas
pros:
-Access to Bank Clients
-Lead lists
-Ability to leverage relationships within the branch to accelerate investment relationship
cons:
-Internal competition with Private Advisor, Wealth Group, Portfolio Manager and Scott & Stringfellow
-Branch employees have zero accountability to drive investment revenue
-Branch employees have no understanding or training in how to approach investment relationship opportunities
-Senior management doesn't care about the plight of the investment counselor
-Lack of wrap accounts, products and brokerage abilities
-High cost of products prices us out of many sophisticated clients
-Lack of financial planning software to present plans to clients
-Overall, a very Stone Age experience to investments and too much conflict internally leaves the investment counselor feeling like they're on an island that no one cares to visit.

review_title: Female-Dominated Workplace Where The Abuse Goes To The Top
job_title: Collections Representative I in Lumberton, NC
pros:
The starting salary was fair. 
Employees are pretty sedentary, not a lot of moving is required -- if that is a pro.
cons: I worked in Collections. With over 300 employees in my location -- and most of them female, workplace bullying was a HUGE issue and management did not care. BB&T does NOT respect diversity. Comments were constantly being made against homosexuals. During my training a woman from HR came and spoke with us, stating that our location has had problems with that kind of thing before and it would not be tolerated. BB&T also claims to have whistleblower protection but that means nothing! I was treated very badly by management after reporting hugely offensive comments that were allowed to be made and joked about. This is a competitive, female-dominated workplace and its extremely hostile -- not worth the salary whatsoever! Collections is also based in Lumberton, NC so that has a lot to do with the environment. I had 3 bosses, each more pretentious & unprofessional than the last. I ended up quitting. The supervisors are callous, bloated and the entire workplace is a huge joke. My time is worth more.

pros: Overall good benefits and it's a pretty secure job.  Depending on the department you work in, you could get promoted fairly quickly by working hard to get noticed.
cons: Poor management and dictatorship like tendencies.  Promotions in my department are based on who can flatter the boss the most.  You can't speak your mind or go against the grain.  If you do speak out in a respectable way, you are shunned and black-balled until you can prove yourself to be more "like them."  you have to watch what you say and who you say it to.

pros: Good Benefits,  if you are just out of college the Leadership Development Program is a good path.   At least it is a solid, conservative bank that will not be going out of business.   Good values as expressed in regular speeches by upper managemen, the 10 core values.
cons: Management feels that 0-1% raises are good enough for most employees in almost every year, good or bad.  They treat the LDP graduates as if they are made of gold wheras the typical employee is much lower valued.  Very little communication on issues that might affect you.  Do not live by the "justice" value when it comes to items like annual reviews, typically the grading scale is shifted down where if you perform to your job you are not getting an annual raise.

review_title: Good leadership is integral in a recession and the bank has done a poor job of creating a motivating environment
pros: up to 6% matching 401K, flexible time off however vacations start off at a paltry two weeks
cons:
- poor leadership - micro management is rampant and feels like certain managers do not genuinely care for their staff, only how they appear to their bosses and exec management
- pressured to cross-sell products that clients don't need so that managers can look like they are doing their job - short term approach that counters the bank's "relationship banking" philosophy
- constantly need to report calls/referrals - should look at the bottom line instead
- poor technologies which create redundancies and inefficiencies. Recently invested lots of time and money training for an ineffective software that was confusing to use
- credit is understaffed, therefore deal decisions are delayed

pros: No pros that I can recall.
cons:
1.  50-60 hour work weeks.  
2.  Pay is pathetic compared to the competition.  
3.  Very political organization and hard to move up within the ranks if your not smoozing with senior management.  
4.  Call nights several times a month (which do not guarantee any further sales results).  
5.  Sales, Sales, Sales, Sales driven - Senior Management is highly driven by your production figures.  
6.  Monthly sales meetings are the same bunch of bogus every month (area managers talk down to us like we're elementary children ..."remember to always open a checking account, blah blah blah).  
7.  Never had an opportunity to recruit and select my own staff from interviewing.
8.  Constant shortage of staff within branch - yet goals are still held to par (in 2012 I averaged 1 teller).
9.  Inconsistent underwriting among managers.
10.  Vacation times only permitted if appropriate coverage within branch.

....the list goes on...

review_title: I'm a number, nothing more, and will be leaving soon
pros:
Benefits package
Lower level employees are genuinely good people
Good place to start a career, emphasis on start
cons:
Management (at all levels - low, mid, senior) I've worked with/for every level
Salary
Promotional Opportunities

review_title: "Safe & Secure @ BB&T?" Not if you are employed there!
pros: Benefits are very good, including health, dental, 401K, pension.  Education is promoted, but only for things that will make $$ for BB&T.
cons: Benefits keep you "hooked" whether you want to stay in your current job or not!  Profits, trips, etc., earned in each office all go to corporate execs and stockholders, not shared at local level fairly.  Furniture, equipment is out of date and worn, offices are in less desirable and unsafe part of city.  "Safe & Secure" corporate policy is a joke when desk drawers are so old they won't even lock anymore!  Everyone who has left employment in past 7-8 years knows the security code to gain entry into our office.

review_title: Not a bad company to work for (collections department)
pros: The health benefits, 401k, and FSA are great. The pay is fair enough.
cons: The job in and of itself by nature (collections) is stressful. This is not helped by the fact that the company has made some major blunders in the last year and not handled transitions well.

job_title: Default Support Specialist in Greensboro, NC
pros: The hiring process was fairly easy. They fingerprint and run background checks just like any other bank.  401K,  2 weeks vacation,.
cons: Its definitely an old boys club there, no new members allowed. If you do too much they feel intimidated, but if you do to little, you get disciplinary actions taken against you, so you have to find a balance even if they give you a huge work load. The managers in that department are unaware of their associates duties and their own because their training is poor. Nothing is documented, everything is a lecture, mostly via conference call from the associate that does the job or previously did the job. Often times they purposely leave out important information that would aid with the your job.

review_title: Was a great place.....until they closed our center.
pros: lots of training for your particular job, great people, great benefits, lots of flexibility in work schedule.
cons: After 3 years of getting the Center up and running, providing weeks of training to each associate and all working a lot of overtime-the closing of our center has been very disappointing. Being part of a reduction in work force is the worst! Too many changes too often-just when you learn something-it changes...again; Officer promotions have no salary increase; the company is so big now, it is hard to know who does what.

review_title: Dont waste your good years investing in a company that does not value or care about their people.
pros: You have a JOB, NOTE* not career.You are employed and are receiving income to take care of your family. There are worse jobs.
cons: Old school ways of managing,promoting,rewarding and retaining employees. NO diversity represented in executive management. Does not value women or minorities. The pay is not competitive and there is no work life balance. The managers all support one another even in their wrong and does not value or encourage open communication and does not value opinions that may differ from the majority. The company is run like a good old boy fraternity. Education is not valued or encouraged, regardless of education or experience individuals are rewarded for who they know.

job_title: Certified Vault Teller in Charles Town, WV
pros: Incredibly rewarding benefits package which emphasizes and rewards optimum health for all employees. They actually paid me extra to maintain good health.
cons: This company seems to not care much how an employee performs but caters to those who have been there for a long time period and can make it unfair for newer employees. I earned countless rewards for superior performance but was still treated like a piece of dirt. This company says they are "for employees" but they're not, at least in terms of work environment! I could sometimes be scheduled one day to open @6:45 am and work til 1pm yet the next day not come in til 1 or 2 pm and work until 6:30 pm. Schedule sucked and I almost always worked 6 days/week.

review_title: Relationship driven bank with an emphasis on compliance
pros: BB&T is very involved in the community. The bank has some very intelligent people working for them. Upper management is outstanding and engaging, you can tell they care about their employees. The benefits are some of the best and BB&T honestly has the best online banking platform compared to the competition
cons: The bank has a lot of red tape. It is important to understand that one of BB&T’s top priorities is to buy other banks and they can only do this by maintaining their clean, solid image and reputation. This makes it difficult to help some clients. Approvals are needed for many things. The banks values are amazing and encouraging however, there is almost a fear-based culture that could make you nervous that you may do something wrong. The current computer systems are not state-of-the-art and sometimes can cause loan errors or other problems that negatively affect the client.

job_title: Employment Consultant IV in Charleston, WV
pros: I really loved the fact that BB&T gives so much back to the communities that they serve.  The benefits are excellent including health, vision, dental insurance. I also enjoyed the communication opportunity for upper management, BB&T is very employee oriented.  There are also excellent time off policies including 10 Federal Holidays per year.  Of course, personal growth is ultimately up to the individual, but BB&T encourages the growth of their employees through training provided by BB&T University.  The work-life balance was sometimes hard to manage as a mother.
cons: The reductions in force in the last couple of years that involved many 20+ year employees losing their job.

pros: Very stable environment. There is tons of institutional knowledge at BB&T. The company STILL has a pension and 401(k). Benefits start immediately. The pay is fair at the company. BB&T strongly pushes it's mission, vision and values consistently. The CEO stands firm on the values and he seems like a fair man.
cons: Benefits are expensive. Company has lots of employees who have been in place for decades which makes the company associates resistant to change and hard to advance. Many of my teammates don't even use instant messaging. It can be difficult to advance in some areas because those associates who have been in roles for literally decades. It's also a "gotcha" environment that breeds mediocrity. Ultra conservative and the company is a "follower". As an example the company's mobile app just started allowing (2015) mobile check deposits through the app. Most banks initiated that process many years before. Company has issues with diversity at mid and high levels of management.

review_title: Great employees and good work/life balance.
pros: Most employees are very good people who are great to work with and are trying to do the right thing.  There are very few people who play games or back stab.  Employees are treated fairly and promotions and pay increases go to those who contribute the most (sure, there are always a few exceptions when you have a company of this size).
cons: Some work locations are not very exciting (Lumberton NC, Whiteville NC, Charleston WV, etc.).  Many buildings are old and in desparate need of updating.  Like many companies, the sales side gets the most recognition while the back office isn't recognized as much for successes.

review_title: An old school company that is unwilling and unable to change.
pros:
The pay was decent and my co-workers created a good environment.
As with all things, it depends on your manager and their manager (that's the secret) make sure you interview with both and grill them.  If you're at the interview they want you... now just make sure you want them too!
cons: "But we've always done it this way" is a motto of many banks, but executive leadership that has been with the company their entire career make this a top down culture that doesn't understand or embrace change and technology.

pros: This is the best call center I have ever worked for. They actually care about you as an employee and appreciate you. The manager is down to earth and knows everyone by name and even a little bit about you personally! Which is awesome. There is room to grow and after your grace period you can apply for other positions.  This call center actually wants you to stay unlike other centers who just use and abuse you until they fire you or you quit. I recommend this company if anyone decides to apply for customer service
cons: Only cons I can say is that they don't have a point system for abscence, it's "supervisor discretion" this is an unfair business practice! Someone can miss ten days and still have their job whereas another person can miss theee days and be fired if their supervisor says so! Therefore it sucks for the people who have supervisors that don't like them

pros: Benefits, values, locations, associates
cons: Poor Leadership,  Human Services isn't confidential at all.  Work Life balance,

pros: Benefits and Pay are good.
cons: Pay not equal to position (tellers and BB's make very similar pay with a huge difference in responsibility and job functions) and training is highly inadequate for handling customer money.  We run short staffed and every banker is working teller line every other day-while still trying to maintain our sales quotas.

review_title: Great benefits and compensation but pace of change is very slow
job_title: Enterprise Security Architect in Raleigh, NC
pros:
Excellent benefits
Excellent Compensation
Excellent Job security and stability
Excellent Culture in terms of politics. Leftist pandering is much less than a typical large corporation in America
cons: I feel that its hard to make any meaningful change. There is much talk about doing things but nobody ever does anything. Its a great place to park yourself and collect an excellent salary but don't expect to make big changes or to be a change agent. The organization is heavily resistant to change and doesn't like those who ask for change.

review_title: Fantastic opportunities for just the right person at just the right time in their career.
pros: Company reputation.  If you are willing to move, great career opportunities for those willing to work extremely hard and smart.
cons: Overall it is a good place to work.  In my case I have two managers for whom the word is a misnomer.  I see other areas where employees are working well together and where common sense and respect rule.  In my area one manager plays favorites while the other manager is not capable of adjusting to the fact that four or five of those who report to this manager are more capable.

review_title: Decent job for someone in college but not for a career after college
pros:
- Good benefits
- Good people
- Easy work
cons:
- Takes a long time to advance in most case, it's a policy that you must be in a position for 18 months before you can would be considered for another role
- Moving to another region it is unlikely to be promoted and instead you must stay at the same level or take a demotion
- A teller with a BS in Bus. Admin with < 3.0 GPA will find it next to impossible to advance beyond that position for this company within a year

review_title: If you are fortunate enough to get hired here, don't ever leave.
pros: BB&T knows how to take care of their employees. This bank pays better than any other and you get an incredible work/life balance. Many banks are notorious for giving tellers pitiful pay and then breathing down their necks for referrals-not here. They provide you with the proper training and compensate you beyond fairly. I've truly adopted another family working here.
cons: Although this is more-so a con for clients rather than employees, the company is a little "behind the times". Slowly but surely they are rolling out new technology (envelope free ATM's, improvements to the mobile app) which will help the company keep up with the "big banks".

pros: BB&T purchased National Penn Bank in 2016.  As with any transition there were positives and negatives.  The people in the organization were very nice and helpful.  The company treated the National Penn staff whose positions were eliminated very well and fairly.  They provided a good severance package and outplacement assistance.
cons: BB&T is very functionally driven.  Often employees in different functions asked for the same data and in other cases they were not on the same page.  In addition, most of their staff was task focused and often didn't consider their impact beyond their line of sight.  All good people trying to do the right thing and a good job, but not experienced or driven to think broadly.  This is not uncommon when working in a large company who is growing quickly.

pros:
The company has a  philosophy of not doing business with companies that practice eminent domain. 
The company offers a lot of training.
cons:
They began to alienate clientele by requiring high balances and fees in checking accounts during a time when a lot of people were already struggling to make ends meet. FMLA means nothing since you can be terminated for having to leave to care for a child covered under FMLA. 
A lot of cliques. If you're not part of one then you may have issues. Even if your manager feels that you are ready for the next step in your career path, you can bet there is someone around who is trying to prevent that from happening. Yet, there are others being promoted with less experience.

pros: Not much is asked of individuals.  Initiative is not rewarded nor expected.  If you work here and do not rock the boat you can work here for pretty much your entire career.
cons: Mediocre talent pool.  The best managers and bankers do not work here...they go someplace else and make more money.  BB&T does not pay market and as result the overall quality of its employees is pretty much the same across the entire platform...not very impressive. The employees who do work here love it, because they know as long as they stay in line, not much will be asked of them, and they wont get fired.  They also know they cannot get a job elsewhere doing the same job for equal or more money, because they  are not as sharp as their peers (otherwise they would have some gumption and not work here).

review_title: BB&T is a financially secure institution
pros: BB&T is a financially secure institution and thus far has weathered the economic storm welll.  BB&T is a large regional bank but (for the most part) is run like a community bank.  This allows the leadership for each region to have some input on how their region is managed.  BB&T has strong core values including honesty, integrity, productivity, team work, independant thinking, pride, justice, reason, self esteem and pride.  BB&T uses it's core values to guide their everyday relationships with clients and employees.  It is definately the most ethical organization that I have ever worked.  The CEO takes the time to vist each region quarterly and update its employees on BB&T's past successes and where it sees the future of BB&T.
cons: Sometimes it seems that  manangement doesn't value employees that aren't in a direct "sales" role.

pros: Good benefits, decent pay, good hours.  Training programs are easy to use and are very helpful to understanding the job itself.
cons: Referral goals are becoming hard to sustain.  Some supervisors are so more worried about referral/sales goals than customer satisfaction.  Most of the clients who come in every week are the same and do not want to constantly be badgered about getting a credit card or adding on other services.

job_title: Personal Banker II in Boca Raton, FL
pros: The products that they provide to customers work well for being a conservative bank.  They have a very intuitive training program and they really want you to learn their company values and what they provide to their clients.  Benefits are pretty good also.
cons: Compensation is not up to par for what you are demanded of.  When they moved into South Florida, I don't think they did a good job of transitioning into that market.  They try to force client's to their values and if the client doesn't like it, it's like they didn't care.  Also there was really no support for their employees. Upper management is terrible when it comes down to getting support to the front line workers.

review_title: It was good experience for those that want to make a career in banking.
pros: Bankers hours. You get to have an hour lunch, off all the major holidays and you get 2 weeks of vacation time as a full time employee with the option to purchase an extra 5 days.
cons: It's kind of slow to advance from being a teller. My supervisor was not professional at all and immature. When I get a referral the branch banker got the incentive not the tellers. Expect to get shopped by fake customers who will grade how well you do at your job. You have to welcome everyone that walks in the door with a "welcome to bb&t." Like a robot almost. Doesn't come off as sincere at all. And expect to be treated like a child and micromanaged as well.

job_title: Product Marketing Specialist in Richmond, VA
pros: Not micro managed, allowed to use full breadth of resources to expand the my position  to accomplish more than what is expected/ No set production goals, but always strive to outpace previous year's production through all methods of sales and marketing. Bonuses available for Specialist level, and have received  1 raise in 3 years.
cons: There is only 2 in the department which includes  department manager. Phone coverage is mandatory at all times, so It is difficult to both be out of the office at the same time.  Salary  plus bonus only - no commissions based on assisted sales.  Salary  currently under 60k - should be higher, and  personal bonuses have ranged from $3K to $5K which should be higher given the contribution to overall revenue.  Bonuses are not tied to anything , so you never know if one is forthcoming and how the amount is determined.

review_title: Love the culture and benfits, but management is shady
pros: 401 k, insurance, pay is ok
cons: management works together in coming down on the little people.  If one manager does something unethical their management backs them 100%.  Leaving the little guys to fend for themselves.  Human Resources is a joke.  You report something being done to you and they help cover the unethical manager and come up with a plan to get you fired for reporting the incident.  Rarely have coverage when an employee is out sick you can count  on not having a lunch if you have overtime they will find a way to send you home or make you take a 2 hour lunch some other day. Micromanaging is an issue. Under educated people with no managment skills get hired off the streets mean while loyal employees that keep the company running and keep clientel coming back have no room for growth.

job_title: IT Process Analyst in Winston-Salem, NC
pros: BB&T is great to employees.  They're a very fair Cosby, and there's plenty of opportunity to advance from within.  The average tenure here is over 15 years, and I can see why.  Good culture.
cons: In an effort to hire more millenials, the company sometimes looks more at degree than skill.  Salaries lag the rest of the industry, but we're improving.  The aversion to telecommute is a little strange given that most of the industry offers some type of flexible schedule or location.  Systems were dated, but there are major technology efforts in flight to address.

review_title: Overall, a good company to work for
pros: They start you with 10 vacation days plus 10 paid federal holidays off and give you an option to purchase up to an additional week of vacation. There's a free employee health clinic that's separate from you're health insurance. No copay or deductible, and they even give you free prescriptions. Of the banks that have tried recruiting me, BB&T has a higher base salary. The company minimum wage is $15! The department executives are very approachable.
cons: Being in a difficult branch can make it difficult to advance your career. No opportunities to earn incentive bonuses. Some of the processes are outdated. Also certain departments have zero diversity (I'm not sure if that's just by coincidence)

review_title: A big bank at its "best"...One acting opposite of the core values the bank advertises
pros: Most people that work at BB&T are very friendly and down to earth. A select few who completely subordinate personal interest to the bank have good career opportunities. You are guaranteed to be "promoted" if you stay long enough, regardless of work quality. BB&T offers very competitive benefits. Pay is mediocre.
cons: BB&T is incredibly inefficient. Wasteful spending abounds and spending in critical areas is anaemic. BB&T's compensation is not competitive. The entire bank is built with inefficient systems and an insider could see that the bank is built like a house of cards. Products are not competitive with competitors.

pros:
This is a good place to learn a lot about business, processes, and business politics.  I sincerely mean that.  After working at BB&T and at other places without any processes, I have learned that there needs to be a balance (some but not too many, make sure you have the right ones).

BB&T offers decent business and leadership training.   I enjoyed many of the courses and learned a lot about myself.
cons:
These might have just been related to our area:
- Too many reorganizations.  Change the structure and let it be for at least 2 years.  You don't know if something is effective after only a year.
- Too many meetings. 
- Too many circular meetings which relates to
- No real direction.

For the company as a whole:
- Too much inter-department fighting and jealousy when the departments have a bit of overlap.
- Still too much of a "good-ole boys", conservative environment

pros: No one looking over your shoulder all the time. Got 2 raises while there--had to ask for them.
cons: Worked long term full time temp for over 6 years. I was never hired by BB&T. Manager hired & gave special attention to employees who went to her church. More concerned about quantity than quality. Atmosphere was noisy with a lot of socializing (had to wear earplugs). Many who worked there ignored me. A few were nice. The boot-lickers were the ones promoted. May not have been hired due to my age (63 when I left) or political affiliation. New hires were paid more than long time workers. As higher pay was given to new hires, workers already there did not get raises to their level.

review_title: Good place for someone in middle of career.
pros:
Wonderful retirement plan. Good 401k and defined benefit pension plan. 

Senior Management makes an effort to connect with employees through video series, surveys, Q&A

Compensation is fair

Very supportive of community involvement either individually or corporate sponsored. 

Company is in favor of work-life balance (generally). 

Telecommute opportunities are available for certain roles
cons:
Large company problems (heavily silo'd, lots of red tape when trying to get things done)

Lagging behind in the implementation of internal technology

Compensation increases are often mediocre so you'll need to be promoted or move around a bit to get sizable pay raises. It's difficult for managers to truly reward high performers.

job_title: Client Service Associate in Richmond, VA
pros: Co paid benefits are excellent and inexpensive, including company-funded pension plan. Vacation and holidays and adequate and comparable to other large employers.
cons: Unreasonable workloads; overtime is rewarded with even more work but no overtime compensation. Management demands reduced staff keep up with "service standards" and new business, including endless meetings to discuss how to increase revenue for BB&T.  After working for a year, the most raise anyone can expect as a top performer is still only 2%.  Current employees work in fear of disapproval of management and are afraid to speak up and say what they think.  When an employee leaves, management puts them down to remaining workers on a regular basis.

pros: Benefits    The so called Perfect Client Experience philosophy...it just needs to be consistently enforced.
cons:
Good ol'e boy system           Not what you know but who you know that gets you promoted
Management still running the bank like a small town bank rather than a progressive regional bank

review_title: Good outward appearance, drama at the branch level
pros: Extremely thorough training. Good matching % 401k. Bank has a great growth story in the South as well as some very loyal customers
cons: Technology wise, not the most up to date Bank. Branch/real estate is quite old not as many new branches. behind the curve on updates all the way around. Average age of customers 65-70 yrs old, needs to make changes to attract younger clients as well, that might appreciate the wider range of products. From branch to branch I experienced quite a bit of inner office drama centered around young inexperienced management that spent a lot of time gossiping about others around them.

review_title: Do NOT work for BB&T if you are in the Information Technology or Information Security fields!!
pros: Health Care and trust me you'll need it after working there for any length of time.
cons: Internal politics are horrific!! Senior level managers only listen to those that brown nose them to a horrifying level. You need to have good health care to help with the dread and nausea you have when showing up to work every day. Any time I hear of someone thinking about working at BB&T , I warn them over and over as there is so much opportunity in the Raleigh area, there is NO reason to work in Wilson!! Management knows it's bad, and really doesn't care.

pros: "Status" job with excellent benefits package. Continuing education is promoted for all positions; liberal paid holidays, company-sponsored wellness program, but Krispy Kreme doughnuts every Friday!
cons: HEAVY workload, unreasonable management expectations of producers and support staff.  Producers are held to new sales goals in soft market that are difficult to attain while under the pressure to retain >95% of renewals. Bonus for support staff is dependent upon these unreasonable goals, but we have very little control over the success or the outcome.

pros: Great benefits and can be a fun place to work if you don't mind sales and learning to do everyone's job in branch.  We all covered each other for leave or lunch. Company preaches a great message to employees, but fall short in execution.
cons: Manager was never in building.  Company too interested in getting new business, rather than keeping current clients happy by providing enough staffing.  Branch goals were usually out of reach.  Drove to other branches nearby to cover shifts.

review_title: Good company, depends on where you start at
pros: Sr Management does things to keep employees happy, such as giving you your birthday off.  Benefits are very good, especially for singles.
cons: The pay is so-so for the industry.  Biggest drawback is opportunities for growth, you may be told one thing at one point, but then something completely different.  Depends on the department, but from my experience and others I know, management that actually cares about personal employee growth versus how their review looks is harder and harder to find

job_title: Financial Center Leader II in Orlando, FL
pros: Insurance is great but expensive
cons: North Florida retail management will lie as often as needed to make them selves look good. We were told repeatedly that no one was in danger of losing their job. Yet, several people did lose their positions and several were forced to move to unsuccessful branches. Was this an attempt to get them to leave the company? If you play the "good ole boy" game with the men you have a good job of being successful. Talk football, golf and hunting and all will be well.

review_title: Cutbacks are going to kill them in the end
pros: This is a great company to work for. They have wonderful benefits. Getting my birthday off each year is great.
cons: This is a "good boy society". If you do not fit into that mold it is difficult to find yourself advancing. The new branch positioning is not going to be a good move for their clients or the personnel that is left in the branches.

review_title: A pretty surface with some messed up management...
pros: Benefits, PTO, pension plan, great health club called Life Force that encourages a healthy lifestyle for discounts on the health insurance. Employee camaraderie! Lots of teamwork.
cons: Short staffed, management can be tough on people. They don't like it when you try and get the truth. The market leaders tend to snitch on other employees and if you do something to upset one manager, you can get blacklisted.

pros: Came onboard because core values mirrored my personal core values. Direct manager who valued my input and expertise and gave autonomy to make decisions.
cons: Core values have been lost in regional level management.  The bank has cut associates with longevity of ten, twenty and thirty plus years to bring in younger and less experiences associates. Staffing in branches is less than adequate where associates get no break for lunch unless manager steps in to work for them as a teller or customer service.  Operations support is non-existence and staff fears their dictatorship when they do show up.

pros: nothing really. only positive thing for me is that it's close to home.
cons: Summer 2013 they cut a bunch of managers and clustered them to be over 2 or more branches. Summer 2014 they did an additional cut and now managers are clustered to maybe 4 branches minimum. They cut the hours of a bunch of tellers from full to part time to further save on expenses which puts extra workload on the 1 full time employee at the branch with no pay increase. Very unrewarding and stressful and the part timers now have a financial burden with the pay cut. They think it's acceptable for clients to have extended wait times with only 2 employees at the branch which is a security risk.

review_title: Good but scary place to work
job_title: Certified Senior Teller in Murray, KY
pros: Work load is reasonable, easy to learn and cross-train. Loved getting to know clients. Very good benefits. My insurance for just me was free. I was actually paid $30 a month to have their insurance. A program called Life Force made that possible. I miss that more than anything else about the job. I made life-long friends there too, that's important.
cons: Micro managing!!! Hated being told what to do from people in Louisville. Lately they have "eliminated positions" like nobody's business. Teller is the only stable position in the company. As a teller I felt like I knew all there was to know after about two years. Made me lax and uncommitted because there were no opportunities to advance.

review_title: 30-Hr Relationship Banker II (Save the World Worker I)
pros:
Part Time benefits (insurance/401k)
Decent Pay
Paid Vacation
Great co-workers
cons:
Sales pushy
Lack of schedule flexibility
Time off (weird system of vacation selection)
Bosses throwing you under the bus
Having to keep a straight face when you'd really like to tell the person in front of you "YOU overdrew.  This is completely YOUR fault!) 
Horribly scripted save the world speech to new "clients"

pros: I love the clients and the fact the BB&T offers a 401k and pension, health, dental, vision, life, ad&d.
cons: Banking is a constantly evolving industry. Staffing has been cut thru attrition and turnover to fit into business model of every one is a Universal Banker. Less staff, higher responsibility, more stress. Company is becoming EXTREMELY sales driven instead of service driven. Also new hire training has recently been revamped and is extremely poor.

pros: Benefits and incentives for employees, plenty of locations making it convenient for potential clients.
cons: Shady management who focuses on bogus goals similar to the recent Wells Fargo scandal.  They talked of "doing the right thing" out of one side of their face but wanted you to lie, cheat and/or steal to get production.

review_title: Read the Values, Vision and Mission
pros: Values Driven organization.  BB&T has a clearly defined Vision and Mission Statement, and is one of the very few financial services companies who actually maintains consistency with it's stated values.  BB&T is true to it's commitment to Client, Employee, Community and Shareholder.
cons: Slow to embrace new technologies.

review_title: Really dissapointed in how this company has changed
pros:
Excellent Benefits! One of the few companies who still give you a pension after 5 years of loyal service. No 90 day probation before health care, dental, etc. 
Job stability: If you are in a sales related role (which 90% of jobs are) you are pretty much safe as long as you do your job.
cons:
Everything is a secret. Nobody can give straight answers on when new employees will be hired, how long a situation will last, or what is being done to fix it.

Very slim on staff. They will work you to the bone...with NO overtime. Instead of one day off a week when working 6 days a week, you might come in at 9 and leave at 11...complete waste of time!

job_title: Mortgage Loan Processor III in Greensboro, NC
pros: Good benefits, there is the Life force program which helps encourage good habits and rewards. The Lighthouse project done once a year is biased however.
cons: The challenges outweigh the pros. Understaffed, technology is thoroughly outdated, very slow and rarely works properly. Training is minimal, and if a class does come up, management says no, they only let a select few go. Jobs are never posted, people are just placed in those positions. Upper management lets all of this happen. They condone it. Certain employees do what they want. Management allows it. It just depends on who you know.

pros: Meeting clients and building relationships. 401k and benefits. That's about all I can say that is positive in that place besides having the holidays off.
cons: This place does not care about their employees. $15 gift every Christmas to eat with and if you don't go eat with your office then you don't get the $15. The incentive program is a joke. If you don't meet a certain dollar amount then you don't get any of the money you worked for. Everyone is a number and this company is becoming greedy. Used to be a good place to work for but their customer service opportunities are awful.  The raises in that place are pathetic. Maybe 20 cent a year if your lucky.

job_title: Real Estate Evaluator in Charleston, WV
pros: The ability to work independently at home was perfect.  The benefits were perfect.
cons:
My team leader and the other members of my team were located in Virginia and Maryland; I was the only evaluator in WV because I was the only candidate for the job who knew as much as I knew about the state.
The team leader and all other members are male.
My team leader thought he was helping me, but I suffered constant harassment and negative criticism from him.  The harder I worked, the more they expected.
Finally, the men were paid more than I was and were promoted while I was held back, receiving only a single 2% raise in 4 1/2 years.

job_title: Financial Center Leader I in Baltimore, MD
pros: They promote from within, I started as a Relationship Banker and went through the Management training program to become a branch manager/retail loan officer.  Opportunities for bonuses based on meeting sales goals.
cons: More worried about making numbers and sales goals than the well being of clients and employees. Work a lot more than 40 hours a week but don't get paid overtime for salaried employees. A lot of focus on cold sales calls both by phone and in person. Goals do not always reflect the area the branch is located in.

pros: Benefits are fantastic, flexibility with hours
cons: Have to be in a position for 18 months before being ale to apply for another internal position without letting your manager know. Managers have been known to prevent internal movement for their own selfish reasons.Tuition reimbursement is a joke. In class only for a measly $3000 reimbursement on a 4 year degree. Training is disastrous. Upper management doesn't spend enough time in the branches to know what's going on day to day.

job_title: Relationship Banker in Virginia Beach, VA
pros: loved all fellow co-workers, great networking opportunity through surrounding small business, plenty of opportunities for training.
cons: micro-managed by Branch Manager, robotic and phony scripts are given to the point of embarrassment.  no room for advancement, sales goals that are met are never appreciated.  The worst part was the assumption you have no life outside of work, you are walked on, expected to come in when called on weekends or vary your schedule at the drop of a dime, expected to work ten hour days with only 30 minute break multiple times a week.

job_title: Financial Center Leader II in Montgomery, AL
pros: Life force health insurance and good training programs for your job.
cons: Financial Center Leader, Branch Manager, Market Leader.  Depleted branch staff, heavy sales goals, cold call nights, sales. They laid off several jobs over the summer 2013 so check the reviews since then. Its resulted in poor customer service and 60 hour work weeks.   If you're in the branches, its all about product pushing and sales goals just like any other big bank. They increased fees on customers rather than updating loan policy to generate income. Basically, I think BB&T is good to work for if your in the back office, but its difficult if your in a client facing position in the branches because you have limited staff and you have no authority to make decisions.

pros: The pay was great  and the benefits were nice. The place had great culture, rotating around the perfect client experience.
cons: old system, constant system errors, outdated technology, cheap, pushy in credit card sales, and way too much drama for a bank. It's not an ideal work environment, and the system is extremely sensitive and error prone. Plus, they cross train their employees and set quota's that are IMPOSSIBLE to reach. The company has a great culture and atmosphere, but without updating to the current era (their system is 30 years old), they will fail.

pros: Great Benefits.  Reasonable pay.  Quality people.  Good Reputation.  Solid company that will most likely survive for some time to come.  Growing mostly through acquisition.
cons: So bottom line focused that often employee needs are ignored.  It is an "all-in" mentality that requires allegiance but that does  little to promote true teamwork.  So structured in the old school Jack Welch method of bottom 10% must go and the outdated performance evaluation system that often true talent is not recognized.

review_title: Goals to High or unattainable for smaller markets
pros: They were good when they first took over our Colonial Bank, Lots of support and training.
cons: After 2 years they became the wicked "stepmother" Getting rid of all the older people that had 15+ years to avoid paying the higher salaries. Not good to employees, Always asked to do more with less, They change titles too much. After hours call nights to get accounts.

review_title: Nobody is perfect, Capitalism like any other philosophy taken to extremes will create problems.
job_title: Business Analyst IV in Winston-Salem, NC
pros: Training is offered for a variety of jobs.  Much of it is a waste of time but does give employees some time off their demanding workloads. in this way perhaps it does accomplish something.  It sure feels like indoctrination rather than training though.
cons: It is difficult to advance if you are a recent hire. The culture prevents discourages new employees from contributing.The culture prevents higher managers from interacting with many front line employees for other than ceremonial reasons.

review_title: Strong company hitting hard times due to regulations and outside pressures
pros: The culture is a strong part of BB&T. They make a large investment in training and feedback. I had a great manager, who cared about me both personally and professionally. I always felt respected and supported from within the organization.
cons: The pressure of the banking industry affects all banks, especially large banks like BB&T. There are expected layoffs looming and some departments including commercial banking are feeling the squeeze. Work life balance in commercial and private banking can be very difficult, especially if you are seen as a top performer. Outside pressure causes the bank to be extremely cautious, which makes change slow and work hours inflexible.

pros: If you are looking for a job that pays well with decent benefits, this may be the place for you.  Work-life balance is good and everything looks good on the surface.
cons: Don't expect to come in and grow your career unless you are a part of the good old boy network, brown nose, or can manipulate the higher ups.  If you are a good performer on your job, you'll be rewarded with being stuck in that position.  If you can talk the talk and claim you are always busy, you'll have a very bright future.

pros: A moral company, never been asked to do something I thought was sleazy
cons: Once a year bonus stinks (if you get it), raises are a joke (if you get one - 2% max last year), branches staffed with skeleton crew, technology is worst in the industry, incentive and goal system just doesn't make sense, people are leaving like crazy and those still there want to get out. This used to be a great company.

review_title: Not the great place it use to be to work
pros: BB&T provides excellent benefits.  The company is in a relatively strong financial position and growing.
cons: With the growth that has occurred lately, the client center focus that BB&T has been known for is now second to earnings and goals.  It is starting to feel very similar to many of the big banks.  The culture is changing from the top down.

pros: The benefits such as medical & eye insurance are great. So are the vacation time & holidays.
cons: The micro-managing & recent employee cuts are nerve-racking. Employee morale is low & client satisfaction seems to be declining. I've been with BB&T for a very long time & have never felt as insecure as I do now. I've seen managers come & go. Wish the one we have now would go.

review_title: BB&T is A Great Place to work
job_title: Web Engineer III in Wilson, NC
pros: Challenging position with plenty of training opportunities.  Above average compensation and excellent benefits including 6% 401K match and Defined Benefit Pension Plan.  For the most part the people I work with are great.
cons: Like most companies these days they are taking advantage of the economy and not giving raises like they should.   Sometimes technical decisions are made by middle managers that don't have a clue.  They solicit advice and direction from the Sr. Engineers but often ignore it.

job_title: Relationship Banker II in Glasgow, KY
pros: Extremely challenging work duties. Clients number one priority in assuring they were ask proper questions to place them in products they were entitled to. Fulfilling to help clients to get complete success for financial success.
cons: Heavy stress position. Very little time to relax between clients to gain composure for next client. No time for personal breaks and lunch was always cut short to get back to clients.

review_title: A great place to work and make friends
